text: Bottle..Pour is golden with a hazy white head..Nose is oxidation, stale, spice, caramel...Taste is honey, spice, stale, oxidation..
Bottle at home golden beer, small head, aroma is malt, sweet, fruit. Taste is the same, nice one.

Pours a slightly hazy amber color, topped with lots of off-white head. Nice fruity and biscuity aroma. Taste starts with fruity sweetness, some biscuity notes and mild bitterness in the end. So far, one of best biere de gardes.

750ml bottle. Pours a hazy amber with a medium off-white head and decent lacing. Aroma is caramel, vinous, herbal. Flavor follows, lightly sweet and lightly bitter with lots of vinous qualities poking through. Medium body. I enjoyed this one.

25cl bottle from the brewery in Bavay, 6.5%. Filtered, clear, with no sediment. Clear gold with a thin white head. Oxidized malt gives it a notebook paper and copper penny character that fits with the "house" character of the other Theillier beers weve had on this trip. Sweet, metallic, low bitterness, medium acid, just a tad toffee-ish... light body, thin and watery. Problems here.

Bottle, 0.25l. Slightly hazy deep amber color with small frothy off-white head, millions of floating body particles and sparkling appearance. Aroma is fruity, yeasty, caramelly and a bit honeyish. Taste starts fresh grainy and fruity sour, follows by thick caramel and toffee malt with warming and spicy mouthfeel, while finish is moderate bitter. Medium to full body, thick texture and lively carbonation in palate. Interesting brew with misterious characteristic that I couldnt have thought of, but luckily noticed in CanIHave4Beers rating: ice tea character...

Appearance: very dark amber, practically brown, has tons of particles floating in it, pours with a very large and dense beige to tan head that also has a lot of particles in it

Aroma: plum, raisin, molasses, sweet, faint chocolate, 

Taste: plum, hint of chocolate, raisin, maybe graham cracker, 

Palate: above average carbonation, not too much aftertaste, medium mouthfeel

Overall: not at all a farmhouse ale to me, more like a Trappist beer, lots of plum, a good beer but others do this style better

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a golden yellow with a small head. The smell is big and malty, grain, caramel and grassy hops. The taste is grainy, grassy, malty with a slightly dry aftertaste. Light/medium in body and with average carbonation.
Heller, herb getreidiger Antrunk, helles süßliches Malz. Spritzig, trockene Hefenoten. Nettes rundes Bier. 11/8/10/9/7/9

750mL bottle, pours a cloudy dirty orange with a medium off-white head. Aroma brings out loads of farmhouse notes, fruity esters, and Belgian yeast. Flavour brings out loads of peachy fruit skins, loads of aged farmhouse notes, yeast, and oak. Very complex, dry, and quite fruity. Excellent depth. Wonderful stuff.
Bottle, rated from backlog. Hazy orange with off white head. Aroma and taste of peach, apples, yeast, funk and some malt. Taste is malt, fruit and faint hops.
Bottle 25 cl. Pours golden with big bubbly head. Notes of hay, hops. More like an lager. Nothing too special. "ingenting och hänga i julgranen"

Bottle 25 cl, BBE 12/2013. Pours clear golden in color with a creamy whitish head. Pale malts, some hay and just a bit of buttery notes in aroma. A bit of hay and sweet maltyness in taste. Felt a bit like a lager in disquise.
Smak och doft av beligiskt jäst, malt, metallisk. Tydlig beska och har lagerkaraktär.

Pours a perfectly clear golden color with a lot of tiny bubbles, and a few tiny floaties, the head is a big tight white one and the lacing on the glass is heavy and beautiful. 

The aroma is bready, its got some very interesting dark fruit character, and the booze is a touch too pronounced. 

The flavor I rather like, a little alcohol spiciness, a touch of dried fruit, some nice bright maltiness... the beer is lightly but pleasantly bitter. Its got sort of an Iced Tea character... which is not bad, but it is weird. 

Not sure if this is a very fresh bottle at all, but it is very nice never the less.
Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Hazy amber with an off-white head with a huge amount of tiny floaties. Flavor is sweet, malty, caramel and light fruity. Flavor is quite sweet. Sweet finish. 050313

Bottle. Clear amber with small floaties with small tan head. Aroma is malt, fruit, yeast, caramel, spices and toasted. Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, metallic, medium sweet, hop, yeast and medium bitter.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, malt, grain, bread, fruits and hops.

Nice looking light misty body, orange and glowing, with a firm off white head. Farmhouse yeast, peach, apple compote and some candy. Taste a bit more straightforward, Belgian malts, only lightly hopped although it has a good amount of bitterness. Active, classic carbonation. Not as rich as I hoped. Well brewed beer, quality stuff, but didnt quite satisfy my high hopes. Maybe the ambrée will? (75cl bottle from Bière Révolution)
Sample @ SBWF 12. Amber golden colour with a white head. Sweet breads aroma. Sweat malt bread flavour.

Sample at SBWF 2012.

Hazy light amber with a small head. Aroma and taste of hay, malt, fruit and yeast. Also some bread and dried fruit. An ok beer.
Bottle from Suttree. Clear reddish-amber with almost no head. Aroma of toast, caramel, toffee, and raisin. Taste is moderately sweet, yeasty, and mildly bitter. Medium bodied and slightly dry.
bottle from saveur-biere.com. Hazy golden colour, large and persisitent white head. Malty base with dusty hops and hints of cardboard. Very low carbonation, quite flat.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating.  Gusher upon opening, not surprised.  Pours a cloudy golden orange color with a nice 1-2 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a dense cap that lingers.  Some very nice thick soapy lacing clings to the glass.  Aromas of big pear, grape, apple, lemon, herbal, floral, grass, earth, bread, honey, caramel, and light funk.  Pretty nice and well balanced aromas with good strength and complexity.  Taste of grape, pear, caramel, honey, apple, lemon, earth, floral, herbal, grass, bread, and light pepper.  Light bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of light fruits, herbal, floral, earth, grass, bread, pepper, and honey on the finish for a good bit.  Well balanced flavor profile with good complexity.  Light-medium carbonation and medium body; with a fairly creamy and very slick mouthfeel.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a pretty good Biere De Garde.  Some nice flavor complexity and balance; and quite smooth to drink.

Malt, bread, candy, and some spice in the aroma.  Flavor starts sweet, with caramel, toffee, and maybe a little apple.  A little bittering hops and some drying alcohol in the finish.  Really, really good.
Sample at ÖÖWF 2011. It poured a hazy golden-yellow liquid with a small white head. Smell of honey, berries and hay. Sweet malty and fruity smell. Nice and refreshing beer, easy to drink.

2*250 ml bottles bought in a mixpack and shared at tasting. Pours hazy reddish golden with a rather small frothy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving some trace on the glass. Smell is slightly sweet and tiny our with bread, white pepper, cloves, allspice, lemon zest and hints of barnyard and leather. Taste is sweet, malty and slightly stale with overripe grapes, plums, bread, cloves, crackers and overripe pears. Mouthfeel is round, tiny tart, very tiny dry and medium bodied. Finish is slightly dry with lemon zest, cloves and hints of barnyard.

(Bottle) Pours pale golden with a  creamy white head. The aroma holds spicy wood, pears, apples, grass, herbs, flowers, dew, bread, crackers and dust. Touch of phenols. The flavour is light sweet and light bitter with notes of hops, bread, dough and yeast. He mouthfeel is soft, clean and creamy with a light carbonation. Subtle, light spicy and grassy finish. Light to medium bodied.
Sampled at Larsniclas testing. Pours golden with a big white head. Smells and tastes fruity malty.

Bottle 25 cl, GIL. Pours clear amber with a good off white head leaving some lace. Aroma is grassy malty fruity a bit sweet nutty and bready. Flavor is malty spicy bitter with fruity touch, also some floral tones with some soapyness in the end. Finishes longlived bitter dry.
Bottle at Gott i Lådan, Billdal, 120421. Pale golden, lasting white head. Malty bready aroma, wheat, fruity notes. Bready flavor, malt, hop notes, grassy,

Bottled GIL
Slightly hazy golden. Mdium white head.
Slightly sourish aroma; lemon cest.
A bit sweet and malty flavour; bready.

Ljus och lätt brödig som får mig att tänka bra opasteuriserad/ofiltrerad lager. Ren, fräsch, lätt kropp, ljust bröd, liten men välavvägd beska. Jag tycker verkligen den är lagerlik och kanske i blekaste laget.

25 cl bottle shared with gnoff, sampled on March 10, 2012
Marked 6.5% ABV

Rich yellow color, small white head. Scent of hibiscus, lemongrass.  Sweet, yeasty, cream taste. High carbonation, sweet finish.

Bottle 75cl, a cloudy golden beer with lot of sediment and huge head, light gushing. Nose is grainy. Aroma is sweet, malty, lot of honey and old oranges notes, good body on dry fruit and honey notes. Very drinkable but less impressive that amber one.

25 cl bottle via brekeriet (thanks to Nisse666!), sampled on March 10, 2012Marked 6.5% ABVHazy yellow color, small white head. Sweet, sugary scent, some banana. Sweet, fruity, cream taste. Dry, bitter, cream aftertaste. Moussy mouthfeel, medium high dry bitterness.

Bottle from cons 2012-02-22 Göteborg, wee gusher
Ar: wee yeasty, bread, hops
Ap: golden copper, 1 cm thick fizxy partly deminishing head
F: fizzy, white bread, seads, citric, medium bitterness, steal plate, wee yeasty, mashed potatos

18/II/2012 on tap @ La Capsule (Lille) - BB: n/a (2012-143) 
Clear light orange beer, creamy white head, pretty stable, adhesive. Aroma: some malts, bit of citrus, grains, on warming up some fruit too. MF: good carbon, medium body. Taste: grassy hops, grains, bit of ripe fruit, green banana. Aftertaste: bitter, little metallic. one of the best French beers? Weird.

Bottle picked up at Belmont Party Supply in Dayton a month or two back. Served in a Mikasa tulip.

Pours alight copper color with a very thin white head and a bit of lacing. Thin collar throughout. The nose caries plenty of bread and a bit of caramel. Light earth. Flavor is similar. Really tame, even for a biere de garde. Light-medium body and slightly chewy. Average carbonation. Decent enough, but not a game changer.
malty sweet nose. Taste is malt, slight bitterness and nice yeasty tones. A bit clean for a farmhouse ale in my book, but nevertheless: good stuff. The ambrée was better though.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is mild alcohol, some fruits, mild herbal notes as well as some nectary notes. Flavour is quite similar with some dry wooden notes added.
From a bottle at GBF 2011. Clear golden, medium white head. Grainy malt aroma with some earthy and peppery notes. Dry with medium bitterness. A bit overrated I think.

Bottle at Mosebacke.
Rather heavy for the style, tart taste of hay and oranges, bit spicy.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2011 Bottle.Pours golden with a white head. Sweet aroma. Notes of cookies. The taste is very well balanced. Notes of cookies, currant seeds, and some spices. Small crispness from the hops. Quite dry. Highly drinkable.  I like this one a lot more than the hyped amber one.

Bottle I brought with me back from a stop in Lille. Pours light golden with a huge frothy head that stays, which I suspect indicates the existance of wheat in the malt bill.  The aroma is bready and sweet , but theres a a hint of vegetable in it too, DMS? Its not off-putting but I cant put my finger on what it is. The taste is lovely, malty, bready, some sweetness but it is balanced by a firm bitterness, which gives the beer a dry aftertaste. In he mouth the beer is medium-full with a nice high carbonation that plays with the bitterness.  A lovely beer, and rustic just as the commersial description says.  I wish my local had it on tap, Id be that drunk in Simpsons in notime. I love it!

Bottle @ home. A touch hazy, burnt orange appearance with some black sediment and an ivory head. Opening the bottle resulted in a gusher. Lightly tart, barnyard, Belgian yeasty, a little bready, citrus fruity aroma. A little funky, lemon/apricot citrusy, slightly tart, Belgian yeasty flavor. Very delicious!

Bottled 250ml. -Courtesy of and shared with Marko (thanks!) 
Red label. Golden coloured, small to medium sized white head, interesting but a bit too sweet nose. Very dry honey and chestnut taste with notes of caramel and spices. Sweet finish. Overall a bit too sweet bud nice brew.

Bottle from LAbbaye des Saveurs, Lille, shared with ogivlado. Poured a misty golden body witha big head. Fruity malty nose, slightly tangy, very nice. Pungent strong spicy, heavy taste, slightly nutty. Dry near the end. A lovely beer.
Bouteille de 75cl. Couleur dorée, mousse moyenne de tenue moyenne. Pas nécessairement subtile, elle propose néanmoins un vrai bon goût authentique et généreux. Belle blonde de garde.
Bottle. Pours a golden color small white head. Fruity malty spicy aroma. Fruity malty spicy yeasty flavor. Has fruity malty spicy yeasty finish caramel hints.

Bottle, cracked at Barleys, Knoxville on 8 July 2006, thanks to Springslicker. Golden colour. Earthy aroma, almost with a saison-like touch of farmyard/farmhouse. Strong yeasty notes. Quite a lot of malt for a blonde - mainly biscuity. Decent stuff if not a dazzler.
UPDATED: FEB 1, 2011 Aroma is hoppy, malty, a bit spicy. Clear appearance with nice head. Well balanced between sweet- and bitterness. Sparkling, medium bodied palate. Overall very nice!

Had this brew sitting on a mountaintop somewhere in France. Gushed all over my pants. What was left of it was quite good, fruity and hoppy in a nice balance. A little strange, but that might be just the style. Would have preferred a little more though, too bad I only had half a small bottle left to drink.

750 ml bottle - 

Aroma - aroma has enough dried fruits to make a fruity stand jealous, tons of sweetness, light herbs and somthing that reminded me of light (really light) funk notes.  Very pleasing aroma.

Appearance - beautiful golden yellow body topped with a merengue like fluffy head.

Taste - lots of yeast and dried apple character, sweetness is suprisingly really minimal which is not what I was expecting.  Reminds me in many ways of apple bread, but in liquid form.  

Palate - medium bodied, carbonation reminiscent of a champage or a close cousin of one.  

Overall - a rare great beer from France.  Well worth it if found.  Very nice.

Bottle thanks to SoLan!Red-amber color with a thin white head. Nose of tea, honey, musty wood, and a faint sweet malt in the very back. Spiced flavor, pear, heavy malt, more tea, light peanut. Thin body, lengthy finish with an odd metallic note. Nuanced, drinkable, and unique, but not really a favorite.
Bottle. Clear golden colour with a small white head. Malty aroma with notes of caramel, herbs and grassy hops.

750 ml bottle; thanks to grownfool for the trade; pours light orange with faint haze and foamy white head; grassy aromas of stale wheat, lemons, husky grain and cat pee; very light texture with flavors of spelt, honey and grass; subtle, soft, delicate and just a lovely beer to drink; light and crazy drinkable with a mild creamy mouthfeel; a really tasty BdG

MMmmmm mm! Fab beer, tho not quite as good as the amber. Poured with a nice off white foamy frothy head and good lace. Color is a hazy amber with some dark sediment bits settling out. Aroma is delightful fresh cut grass and clover, spice, malt, yeast, a little fresh leather, hint of apples. Flavors the same with malt emphasis. Great body and carbonation. Super easy drinking, almost hard not to chug. Except for a bit of a greasy end.

Dont hit me, I actually prefer this one to the amber one.

This blonde is yeasty and bready. The bitterness in the aftertaste is fantastic, Very delicate very subtle . I always get this on summertime so I dont know how it handles wintertime.

Golden honey color. Biscuity and spicy aroma 

Taste is bready, fruity and spicy with a delicate bitterness at the end.
It is not smooth. Theres a certain rustic rudeness. It is like a trip in the country, with herbal and floral notes. its main quality : grant this hardness with a more refreshing side. Can be consumed in summer thanks to its refreshing power or winter if you want to focus on its rich flavors

Bottle 250ml.Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, toasted, paper, light yeasty. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration, acrid bitter. Body is light to medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20100111]

Bottle shared at puzzls place: Hazy golden pour with an off white film. Dry, biscuity aroma with a mild herbal presence and apparnt light stricken hops (skunky). Green bottles suck. Light and fluffy body. Dry and biscuity flavor as well. Some bread crust qualities and herbal notes toward the back. It finishes nice and dry. Goes down easy. A solid Biere de garde thats sessionable.

bottle: brought to puzzls tasting: a little skunk and vegetal in the arouma, perhaps due to the green bottle? A little dry, buscuity and fruits. Orange pour and white head. sweet, sticky caramel, finishes dry, pepper and some spice, with some tart.

Bottled. Poofy, fluffy head. Aroma is biscuity, milk, vegetal, tofu. Pretty much dead on for the style. Palate is medium, good carbonation, slightly milky, prickly, with a flavor that shows edamame, dead grass, sugar cookie. Nice BdG.
Clear golden with a tiny white head. Malty aroma with caramel and grassy hops. Flavour was sweet with malt, caramel and grassy hops. Finished bitter.
Tasting at PapsøsBlond color. Aroma of common Lager, paper. It has a respectable body, sweetish but not really malty, with correct bitterness. Crossover between a common Pale Lager and a simple Ale.
Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a huge off-white head. The aroma has notes of matl, straw, and some spices. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and straw, leading to a dry spicy finish.
25 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is dry malty, light cornish. Sweet malty, light cornish and mild acidic flavoured. Bitter and light toasted malty finish.

Bottle 25 cl. Courtesy of Ungstrup. 6.5% in this version. Pours a clear deep golden with a small off-white head. Sweet fruity aroma with some yeast. Medium body, sweet fruit and some warming alcohol in the finish. 110110

Bottle from West Lakeview. Pours a nice looking gold, gushing out of the top of the bottle. Fluffy white head in the glass. Nose is earthy and spicy/herbal hops. A little funk as well. On taste, very floral and again herbal, nice spiciness accompannying a tinge of funk and cleanliness. This is a damn fine BdG.

Bottle. Big head and white lacing. Amber beer. Marzen caramel aroma with a hint of funk and cardboard. Flavour is like a Marzen/Oktoberfest mixed with a Saison. Caramel up front and delicate spiciness through the rest.

I really like the aroma and the appearance.  I was slightly dissapointed in the lack of carbonation and palate.  The aroma has a floral scent that is very appealing.  Great lacing and body as well for the blonde.

Found a bottle of this at State Line. Big time gusher, with a rocky foam head, massive amounts of yeasties in the body, and a nice fruity aroma. Bready malts and only mild hopping (Im thinking this one has a couple years on it?) in the nose. Body is a bit thin, but the earthy, fruity aromas enhance the experience throughout. Light and playful flavors overall, even if the biscuity taste dominates a bit too much. Id say the one thats far easier to find is in fact the better.

Bottle from Nightfall, thanks! Gusher! Golden color. Malty biscuity aroma. Malty sweet cookie dough flavor with a well blended flowery hopbitterness. Butter cookies, flowers, citrus and some perfume in the aftertaste. Maybe a bit too perfumed, but still a pleasant brew.

750ml Bottle (6,5% s written on the bottle). Golden color, huge foamy head and lots of sediments floating around. Malty and strong yeasty taste and aromas with a hint of herbal and grass notes from the hops that give a nice rustic feeling. I find it very enjoyable and refreshing.

75cl bottle from Knightly Spirits (Orlando, FL). Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow color with a thin white less head that settles quickly but provides some lacing on the glass. Yeast cake at the bottom of the bottle was about 1.5 to 2 inches thick --  so thick that we could only pour about 2/3 of the bottle before massive chunks of yeast started plopping in the glass. Aroma is sweet and floral with some ripe fruit,hops, bread, hints of citrus and grain, strong sour yeast notes. Flavor is also sweet and floral with notes of floral hops, honey, yeast, bread, ripe fresh fruit, bananas. Generally light body with a dry finish.

Pours hazy golden orange with big white head. Lightly sour farmhouse aroma with some grassy hops. Bready flavor with caramel and mild earthiness. Medium body with tingly carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Very easy drinking.

In short: A very very very yeasty beer with a nice farmhouse character.  Very nice.
How: Bottle 750ml, consumed when about 6 months old.  Graciously sent my by after4ever, thanks a lot Tom!
The look: Golden blonde body with a enormous amount of yeast particles topped by a large off-white head.
In long: Nose is very countryside, borderline funky, with notes of overripe fruits.  What a chewy and fluffy body this one have, one of the most yeasty beer Ive had.  Soft bready malts or bready yeast, I dont know but it was very bready.  Very doughy.  Citrus fruits, red apples, ripe bananas, barely any sweetness.  A light herbal spiciness.  An overall impression of a big wet grandma fruity muffin from the farmhouse.  Finish is rather dry.  Superb beer for the yeast lover.  Sounds so much better than Superb beer for the bacteria lover.

750 ml. bottle from John’s Marketplace in Portland, OR. Orange tinged gold pour with a huge, frothy white head. Aromas of grass/fruit and underlying breadiness. Seems a bit citric. Medium plus body with frothy, creamy carbonation. Flavor is quite spicy in a noble hop way, with a little fruit, and a light amount of pale malt. Very refreshing. Turns a bit maltier in the finish. I could drink this constantly. I could imagine this is what Westvleteren blonde would be like. Until I get lucky, I can only imagine. Finish has a hint of orange. Damn, but I like it. If Syd died in the wilderness, he likely died happy.

(25cl bottle) Hazy, orange coloured hue with yeast particles swimming around and a moderate blonde foamy white head. Sweet toasted (barley-)malty nose with distinctive notes of draff, spicy hops and alcohol. Moderately sweet flavour, medium bodied with a lively carbonation. Slightly yeasty, draffy and barley-malty taste with a restrained fruit-character (citrus, lime); moderately sweet, slightly bready finish with light herbal spice. Okay, but I think it is a bit overrated (11.08.08).

Pours amber/gold into a snifter.  Fluffy white head roils and leaves sheet lacing as it recedes to hug rim. Orange and lemon joy aromas. Crisp with sweet malt from front to back with a slight bitter hop finish.

Also refreshing and moderately hoppy, with perhaps less malty depth than her sister, Amber. 25 cL bottle at Delirium pours gold with a lacy white head, fading. Nose is grassy, corn-malty, a little sweet. Light, corny sweetness goes dry, grassy and mildly bitter. I can think of so many foods that would be nice with a big bottle of this... How about a cheeseburger?

(3/10/08) 25cl bottle at Delirium Cafe in Brussels. Best before 9/06. Golden color with floaties. Nice aroma full of malt, some caramel, a bit of fruits and a bit of hops. A rather bitter flavor with nice hops and some bready malt in the background. Medium-bodied and softly carbonated. A pleasure.

Bottle bought at Knightly: Slightly hazed with a golden hue and frothy head with very good lace (there were some floaties later). The aroma has notes of grassy and herbal hops, dusty yeast and rustic esters, pear and wheat too. The taste starts twangy and mildly herbal bitterness over a layer of clean pale malts. Some sublime spice notes all about the finish. The mouth feel is lively and crisp, very refreshing. A nice brew and perfect for springtime.

750mL bottle.  Poured slightly hazy light-medium orange with a creamy, well-formed cap of white head.  The nose picked up a bevy of fruity notes and funky, dry spicy yeast.. pale malt forms a sweet backing.. really nice presentation.  The flavor had pale malt and light fruits at the core, supporting peppery yeast, light fruit sourness, and bready notes as it warmed.. refreshing sweet, sour, and spicy finish.  Medium-bodied with active carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.. well-balanced, tasty, and very refreshing.  Almost as good as the regular La Bavaisienne.

Bottle pours hazy and float ridden gold with a large very white head and strong lace.  The head is so strong it feels like whipped topping when trying to sip the beer underneath.  The aroma is slightly sour, spicy, and fruity.  The flavor is, wow, so much happening here that works very well with my senses.  The flavor has some sweetness that is nicely held back by spice and some bitterness that lingers.  The palate is very refreshing, cleansing, and quenching.  This is solid and under-rated.  There is no note of the 7% abv.  I think my new favorite style is either Bière de Garde or Saison.  Yes, this is even more a pleasure as it warms.  I can get more of this.  This will be an awesome camping beer in the Minnesota heat...

Bottle. Large, frothy, fizzy white head with a lot of floaties, virtually no lacing, carbonation observed, slightly hazy, and a straw to golden hue. Nose was sweet, fruity, spicy, and lightly malty. Flavor was sweet, fruity, spicy, malt, and somewhat bitter tasting. Smooth, thin mouthfeel and light in body. Thanks, but no thanks on this one as I could not acquire a liking for the taste. I did not like the way the different flavors meshed or not meshed in this case. Next.
15 DEC 07, Southeast YeHa.   750ml bottle.  Aroma of socks, straw, musty.  Old goat, barnyard and malt.  Light copper appearance.
UPDATED: MAR 1, 2009 clear gold/orange under a small white head.  aroma is grainy, buttery, and moderately sweet.   flavor is crisp and refreshing.  malty with buttery notes.  dry finish.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2009 
Date: December 15, 2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party
Appearance: hazy orange with lots of suspended bits, wispy off white head, drippy lace
Aroma: sweet fruity malt aroma with a light spicyness
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, touch of fruity character, touch of spicyness, lasting bitterness builds out of the spicy character

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3.1/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4

Date: February 14, 2009
Mode: Bottle
Source: Brick Store Pub
Appearance: dark gold, dense creamy beige head, thick lace
Aroma: sweet bready aroma, nice floral character, light spicyness
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, lots of rich bready character like a fresh loaf of bread, light floral spicyness

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4

Appearance: Pours a clear, orange-yellow body with a small, fizzy white head.

Smell: The aroma is a mixture of candied lemons, fresh-picked flowers, as well as dust-strewn peaches and pears.

Taste: Sweet, light maltiness imparts a sugar cookie flavor. Lightly acidic. Hint of yeast. A floral hoppiness, along with the taste of lemons and a medium bitterness help to shoo away some of the sugar for a bittersweet finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Moderate carbonation.

Drinkability: Its good (certainly better than I was expecting).

A dark orange appearance with a large frothy head. The aroma is quite herbal with some lemons and spices. The flavor is quite yeasty with some lemons, oranges, whipped cream, and spices. The finish showed some notes of alcohol. The mouthfeel was very carbonated. Overall a very nice beer.

Pours a slightly hazy golden with a full-lacing white head.  Aroma of sweet sugary pale malt with a touch of earthy hops.  Body starts with fairly full and pale malty sweet with some light fruity esters and earthy bittering hops.  Has a mild complexity and decent drinkability.  A decent Biere de Garde, but I prefer the darker version.

Green bottle.  Wild yeast, grass, and citrus aroma.    Some good notes of sparkling cider.  Pepper and malt, very fruity with lemon and peach - nose is a knockout!  Extremely sediment-rich pour, golden body with a huge rocky cream-colored head, with abnormally copious lace.  Taste is dry and peppery with straw and perfumed grass, prominent malt and a bit of calcium.  Touch of earthy cigar/tobacco, but not ashy or burned.  Really soft and rounded with a slight chalky coating.  Medium body with a bit too much alcohol showing.  Definite Saison overtones, spicy and balanced with neither too much sweetness, spice, or bitterness.  Complex and classy - delicate flowers, individually picked and pressed.  Doesnt quite live up to the initial enticements, but still a really good one.
Bottle. Very saison-ish.  Lots of head and a  golden hue.  Aroma is fruit & earth & other stuff. What one would expect, whatever that means.

25.4 oz bottle.  Cellared for a year.  Cloudy brown with a white head and blanketing lace.  A slurry with the last pour.  Lemon juice and zest; mild peachy malts.  Crisp carb, chewy but not heavy.  Lemon and orange melt away leaving caramel and toffee.  Mellow, bitter finish; some resin.  Beautifully balanced and delightfully drinkable.  Another elegant brew from La Bavaisienne.

A soft easy-drinking blond.  It so goes down easy.  Not overly sweet. Niceheadand pleasant aroma.
A harder-to-get French beer  Worth it.

Thanks to bu11zeye for this great bottle. The pour reveals a cloudy golden color with lots of yeast in suspension and a thick white head. Good aroma of hay, barnyard, field flowers, its farm character is so present that you can almost smell a farmer staning in the middle of the field, but happily, you dont. The flavor has a solid farmhouse terroir with citric grapefruits, hay and yeast. The body has a light to medium thickness with a creamy texture and expansive carbonation. Not as amazing as its big sister can be but still very solid.

Luminous gold. Thick, cakey froth deposits an abundance of intricate lace all over the lace. Dough, fresh straw, grassy hops and candy apples fill the nose as peppery esters tease the senses. Natural carbonation caresses the palate with a pillowy softness. Initially tangy and uplifting yet starchy, sweet, and doughy with a vibrant straw and fresh-bread malt frame. Hop character boasts ultra refined flavors reminiscent of honeysuckle and grass, as well as a clean and assertive bitterness which evokes thoughts of black pepper and aniseed. Minerally grit coarsens the otherwise voluptuously soft body. Elegant malts are squeaky clean and sport a vivid yet delicate honey-glazed sweetness. Yeast leaves its mark with a musty and plastery quality. Finishes with a scratchy bitterness which complements the minerals and accentuates the soft, honeyish malts which linger. An extravagant yet rustic ale thats undoubtedly overlooked/underappreciated because of its  subtleness. Thats unfortunate, because this is yet another brilliant example from Theillier, if you ask me. Now if they would just ditch the green bottles
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
Thanks to egajdzis for sharing this...
Appears a hazy, medium toned gold with a small off-white head that slowly fades out. Scattered lace is left around the glass.
Smell is earthy, notes of caramel, toffee, vanilla cream, yeast, and mild funk.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas with standouts of caramel, cream, and mild spice.
Mouthfeel is medium bodied, creamy, on the sweeter side, and balanced.

Not bad.  The bodys a slightly hazy gold with bunches of swirlies and a thick, creamy, somewhat yellowed head.  Lots of lacing.  The aroma has bicuity malt, orchard fruit and apricots, old flowers, and a bit of soil.  Smooth drinking and slightly oily on the tongue.  The malt gets a tad sweeter in the flavor, but its strongly countered by grasses and an earthy floral bitterness.  Actually a pretty good ale.

750ml bottle share courtesy of egajdzis. Poured a medium golden color witha huge sized white head. Lots of floaters. Aromas of spices, earthy, yeast, and a little funky. Tastes of them same but on the softer side. Thinner body.

Poured a dark golden color with a large, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of earth, skunk, rustic (mushroom), toffee, and bread. Taste of more citrus, vanilla, toffee, earth, and light alcohol as well.

750ml bottle. pours hazy golden with fluffy white head. nose is pretty funky, hay, earthy, grains, spicy hops, nice funky nose. flavor is sorta odd, crisp and funky initially but has a sharp metallic taste that eventually isnt so shocking but not what youre looking for. other notes of caramel, biscuit, and over ripe fruits of pear, peach, and red apple, and slight tobacco. mouthfell is crisp. carb. is lively, alc. is well hidden. lots of sediment in the bottle and impossible to keep away from the pour. slight metallic in finish but its lightly fruity, funky and crisp.

Consumed in my Norwegian Cruise Line glass that I got at the local thrift store for a quarter. Lightly hazed golden body topped by a large dense white head. Very lively. In the bottle there appears to be a good deal of coagulated protein hovering about 2cm off of the bottom of the bottle. The aroma is very yeasty, herbal, apricot concoction. The flavor is quite grassy with some light skunkiness (mishandled in its green bottle I am sure). Luckily it seems that it is only in the early stages of being star struck. LIght fizzy palate. Decent, but a far cry from the other La Bavaisienne.

20060812  750ml bottle shared at Mels Madness.  I dont recall, was this the beer that fired the cork into the ceiling?  Well, it was a fair golden colored beer with sturdy white head.  Nice aromas, fresh and herby with some mild saazy notes.  Has hints of skunkiness but its easy to navigate around that because the beer, overall, is worth it.  Bready, drinkable, all around nice stuff.

Pours a two-finger rocky cream head that fades very slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Cloudy amber color with a ton of suspended yeast.  Skunky nose.  Medium carbonation and light-medium bodied. Flavor is grapefruit and yeast, occasional sweetness, drying metallic finish.  I should have known - its French and in a green bottle.  Not worth $10.00 for a 750ml bottle from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.

Bottle. pours with a golden color and a medium head. Lively carbonation. Bready aromas similar to a European Pilsener. A\Flavors of bread, fruit and a hoppy backbone. Medium mouthfeel with a nice tart finish.

Considering the style, Scores ranging from 1 to 5, 5 being the most intense

Comments: Another extremely yeasty beer from Theillier. If its as variable as the regular Bavaisienne, this rating wont be worth much, but I did find it an enjoyable, sweet pale farmy ale with characteristic musty and almost earthy, salty notes.

A thick layer of creamy white mousse atop a copper orange brew that seemed to have way too much little yeast follicles, it almost looked like Metamucil.

Mandarin oranges, peaches and lychee, with a fresh, pepermint finish.

Soft carbonation for a brew that looked so lively, the yeast is clearly in charge, quite spicy and doughy, with a honey sweet body to give it plenty of definition.  Enjoyable!

My Bottom Line:
A unique union of spicy yeast rusticity, herbal hoppiness, and honeyed malt sweetness creates a soothing farmhouse effect. Nothing less would have been expected of Theillier.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A fleeting frothy foam frolicks atop millions of yeast particles; the honeyed gold gown is surely less sparkling than it could be.
-The yeastiness could get overbearing if one went for the 750ml by himself.
-Cork emanations thankfully evaporated after letting the glass breathe.
-The minty, leafy spiciness tickles my curiosity.

Bottle; no date.

golden amber color with a tall off-white/light tan rocky head.  mostly clear, but yeasty particles at the second half of the bottle.  aroma is grassy and honeysuckle, a bit of lemon too.  flavor is dryish tangy malt like a saison, then some caramel malt like a very weak dubbel.  a bit of yeastiness and dandilion greens.  mouthfeel is light.  finish is lightly bitter.

Amber color with a very tall beige head. Lightly toasted bread with a topping of damp grass and weeds. Hints of attic dust, but it seems to be a bit more musty than dusty. Earthy and woody malts mixed with a spoonful of sugar. Dry grassy bitterness in the finis and linger. Light sourdough and lemon zest also in the finish. Linger is rather dry with just a touch of rust and bitter fruit.
(750ml bottle)  Pours a lightly hazy orange body with a large frothy off-white head.  Aroma of mustiness, lemon, florals, and toffee.  Flavor of caramel, floral hops, and spicy yeast.

Bottled 750. A do-over will be required. Beer has protein chunks, murky, medium-gold colored with a huge, frothy, white, mostly lasting head.

The aroma is malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, cookie, light note of caramel; Hoppy with a moderate note of floral chamomile; Yeasty with a trace of dough, lemon zest; Miscellaneous notes of moderate skunk, honey, light note of cinnamon and cardamom.

The flavor is moderately-to-heavily bitter, moderately sweet with a long, warmish, lightly bittersweet finish.

The body is light, the texture is watery the carbonation is soft.

In the 750 mL bottle from Cyclone Liquors in Ames. Pours golden with a serious amount of carbonation. The head resembles an ice cream sundae. Thick and rich. The flocculent yeast particles float about like sea monkeys. Unfortunately, the wicked green bottle allowed photosensitizing of my bottle and the primary aroma was skunked. Once I got beyond that, the flavor was truly excellent. My best description is lemon verbena. Satisfyingly quick to drink. This would rate even higher by me if they put it in a brown bottle.

Very fruity aroma- apples, pears, melon musk, and citrus oil. Sweet malts, musky straw/grass, vanilla. Complex and addictive. Dull medium yellow clear with fine white lacing head. Heavy watery body with medium carbonation. Sweet start, fruity, with light acidity and no bitterness. Finish is more acidic, and light bitterness is present. Overall, a fruity taste with barnyard/yeasty muskiness. After is light sweet, bitter.

Body is a gold fading to a light amber with a thin off white head.  Aroma is straw, bit of honey, some citrus, light hop content.  Taste has a decent hop bite to it followed by a light content of caramel and is slightly mettalic with citrus.  Good brew.

(75cl bottle) Rocky head the color of the foam atop muddy water, atop lightly hazed apple juice body.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is medium sweet, grassy/herbal, peach.  Taste is medium sweet, grassy, bread, earthy, some herbal, peach.  Soft, medium body, light acidity.
Copper, lots of floaties, solid white head. Aroma is skunky, funkiness. Fruit taste, solid earthy bitterness. Light yeast. Body a touch watery.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2007 Bottle (non-skunked at last!!!).
Head is initially large, frothy, white, fully lasting.
Body is hazy dark yellow, unfiltered.
Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain, bread), moderately hoppy (honeysuckle flowers, herbs, grass), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs, barnyard, cheese), with light notes candied tropical fruit (mango/pineapple) and lavender.
Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.
Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.
Finally got ahold of a bottle (this being my third encounter) that was NOT skunked at all, and that has made quite a difference (if mainly to the aroma score). Beautiful juicy malt-and-hop balance that reminds one of the Ambrée from this brewery. Nifty Brie-like yeast notes. So yes, I have re-scored this as it "should" be, sans lightstruck retailer mishandling...though even when there was slight skunk in the nose, it still got a 3.5 outta me.
A very malty aroma, but still good. Lots of mouthfeel, some simple flavors, but some good hops at the end. A simple, but nice style.

Hazy auburn with loads of floating particles and a tight, tiny bubbled white head.  This has a lovely nose full of sweet malt, light hoppy perfume, mild spice and a hint of warm alcohol.  Toasted grains, orange juice, a malting room floor, light licorice, grains of paradise, orange and grapefruit zest, sticky pine and a hint of toffee.  The body is silky smooth, but with plenty of heft and bright, lively carbonation.  Its fairly sweet up front, especially considering the other La Bavaisienne.  The sweetness gives way to a flavorful hop flavor, full of citrus fruit and pine, more grains and a light bit of warm alcohol.  Its a pretty tasty beer, but not as enjoyable as the original.  The malt is sweeter and not quite as dry as La Bavaisienne.  The increased hop presence is a nice twist, but I think Id rather have a drier version with a more robust and developed malt profile.  Maybe its another example of wishful thinking, but I was hoping for something a little better.  Either way, its still good.

2006 bottle consumed on 9/30/06Staunchly sturdy white/off-white head sits atop a light-goldenrod body, with some slight beige and light-copper tinges.  Tiny bubbles course upwards in the minimally hazy (leaving plenty sediment behind) liquid, supporting the fully lasting head.  Lacing proceeds down the glass in sheets.  Cant ask for much more in appearance.Snappy phenols bound upwards from the yeast, as honey-filled pils malt joins the game.  A strong shot of grassy, herbal hops dries things out, with white and black pepper lingering on the finish.  The yeast is delightfully unique and characterful, just what I remember from the amber version.  It almost defines a biere de garde, giving it that soft, yet distinct mineral character, light almond nuttiness and acidity and an almost cellar-like/musty band-aid character (borderline band-aid).  With the minty, lively, assertive hops, its quite a complete picture in the nose, sporting a high strength of aroma to-boot.  Neither alcohol nor any pils malt brewing flaws (DMS, vanillin, corn-like notes) are present.Succulent honey notes, dripped over fresh, gooey baguette are quickly matched by freshly picked herbal notes coming from the hops.  Dill and mint, oregano and parsley, whatever you want to call it, its dripping with flavor (and a moderate amount of bitterness) and certainly amped up from many of its contemporaries.  Belying the malt strength (in the realm of a double pils), is the tight, invigorating carbonation that breaks up any palate fatigue (certainly aided by the hops) and delivers an engaging experience to the last drop.  The extraction is wonderfully done and the yeast shines strongly on the finish, with notes of almonds, buttercream, strong, slightly bland minerals and plasticy band-aids that I find in the amber Bavai.  No alcohol in flavor, maybe a slight, slight hint of butter.Taken as a blonde belgian ale, or a strong pils, it most certainly comes off too sweet, though taken as a unique creation, in the modern, hoppy, quasi-Biere de Garde sense, it delivers a refreshing charm and uniqueness, or so I think.

Bottle... GABF RB Tasting 06... Mostly clear golden ale with a huge, frothy, white head. Excellent retention. Fruity, malty nose with clover honey and a misplaced note of ash. The flavor is sweet, fruity and breadsy. Light-bodied and watery with gentle carbonation. Sweet, clover finish. Thanks to 1FastSTi for sharing his bottle!

light amber color fluffy well laced white head.  light aroma hints of raw grain some sweet sugars, very raw.  Light fluffy palate nicely coated.  Easy to drink, very light sweet grains and sugars very mellow.  Some light bread notes and a late floral note, a very delicate flavor.

Bottle via The_Epeeist.  Shared at GABF 2006 post-party.  The beer pours to a clean chestnut body with an extremely fluffy white head.  Excellent lacing.  The aroma is nice.  Grain silo, light tartness, crisp, clean.  Nice clean yeastiness.  The flavor is crisp, clean cereal, and grapes with refreshing yeasts.  Clean and delicate.  I enjoyed this one quite a bit.

9/21/06.  Poured out of 750 mL bottle, purchased at Red Carpet Wine in Glendale, CA 9/14/06.  Lightly hazy glowing gold with a gigantic, fluffy and soapy white head, transforming from a dense froth to a rocky, mountainous pillow but lasting impressively long.  Theres a doily lace left behind as the head calms to a "normal" height, and a present-if-spotty lace left behind with each tilt of the glass.  The head fades to a dollop after several minutes, and the lacing actually improves.  Aroma is softly sweet and doughy, prominently yeasty with almost a pale nougat and golden taffy-like spectre of sweetness.  It almost smells like a sweet pilsner (but not an adjuncty mess), suggesting noble hops and straw-like bitterness to round out the farmhouse character.  Lightly acidic with a bold outline of lemon-cookie yeastiness.  Even some touches of cinnamon that I thought I figured in there.  The finish is medium-dry and slightly grassy, suggestive of unsweetened sugar cookies with traces of pepper and white smoke.  The hop presence is strongly intact on the level of some double IPAs Ive had, but theres not an oily, citrusy or piney hint in the least.  Just those lovely noble straw, grass, hay, and pepper notes.  Again very pilsner-like, but sweeter and bigger, badder.  Fluffy, frothy carbonation and slick-but-tangy (yeasty tingles) medium body that makes your mouth water just as the grassy hops and almost absorptively dry finish swath the tongue.  Still seems a little underattenuated (if I may be so bold) with touches of sweetness that arent troubling so much as they are gently disappointing.  Light and airy with an immense drinkability and refreshingness that belies its alcohol content.  A great beer, and still not quite on the level of the "brown."  If one of the locals around here offered something like this (and the only ones I could even see trying it are Pizza Port and Craftsman), Id be dishing that out to all believers.  Recommended to those same believers who previously enjoyed their bottles of Russian River Redemption.

Near copper colour with very good & dense collapsing head, leaving lace. Fresh malts, as on the brewery attic, and after that, quite some dry hops. Caramelly taste, with a bit of kettle-caramelisation (hesitating to say Maillard seen the colour). Caramel stays on, going into a bit greenery finish, but always quite sweet. I seem to get some faint oxydation. Sticky, medium bodied. A bit disappointing. Rather sweet, with not a lot going on.

I believe I have a lot to say about this beer or more like I have a lot of relevant information surrounded around this beer.  Ill start with my disbelief in how my opinions can differ with some fellow RBers that I respect.  You know when one reads just random RBers reviews and disagree with it, its easy to reason it.  For example, this can be a crazy shut in.  However, when its people you have met and respect it becomes weird.  Its not just with this beer but just with other RBers I know and other beers.   So, I bought this at Shoreline Bev, on my first visit now that I officially live in LI.  Cost 6 bucks which is why I went for it b/c I have seen it as high as $11.  Fridged it for a day and opened it up with dinner.   Poured it into my Tripel Karmeliet large tulip glass.  So my expectations were high.  Pours copper with a thick frothy head.  The aroma is definitely pils malt and herbal and grassy as some of my fav reviewers have said.  But at the end, you know what it smells like... like a bad BdG mixed with a Heiniken or a Becks.  Thats that pils, grassy, herbal aroma.  There is some of that malty farmhouse character but weak. Taste is the same.  It does have a slightly sweet aftertaste.  Average mouthfeel and a bit of bitterness.  Just to finish off with this: I really hated French beer untiI I had the regular La Bavaisienne.  I was really excited for this one after that, especially after seeing some of the reviews.  However, I am back on my French beer boycott.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Pours a very foamy high carbonation hazy blond with a massive lasitng white head.  Aroma is very herbal, spicy hops, bready malts light spice, and very similar to the Thiriez Blonde.  Flavor is full with bready pils malts, very herbal and hoppy and finihses fairly bitter.  Nice overall.

750 ml bottle.
A three-dimensional head that resembles beaten egg-whites, tops this spritzy, clear, golden yellow brew.
Some tartness in the aroma, faint spice, Belgian funky aspect.
Very lightly delivered on the tongue, the flavor is slightly tart and earthy. I would have called this a Saison, but I am far from experienced in the two styles. II suspect there are some overlapping characteristics of the two styles. An enjoyable farmhouse style ale in any case.

Sparkling yellow, nice sized white head. Winey, bready aroma, with some notes of citrus. The flavor is rustic, even a little gamey, with some mellow grainy notes. Maybe sourdough? Some herbal notes in the finish. Thanks to Springslicker for sharing this!
Clear golden pour - the aroma and flavor are very herbal and floral, with an almost pilsner-like light hoppiness and grassy character - buttery and spicy - refreshing, but a little thin.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2006 My first thought is that this just has way to many bubbles  -  too much carbonation for me, takes away from the enjoyment of these beers.  Luckily for me, the big head is no reflection of the actual mouthfeel, as its pretty smooth and creamy overall.  This is a very mild biere de garde, with very few spices.  Very herbal, lagered and slightly yeasty/sour.  Some mild fruits, only slightly malty.  Very decent beer.

Golden with copper highlights, decent foamstand but not overly lacey;Hints of orange rind and cedar in the aroma, a little hardwood foresty too...plus GARRIGUE! Well, maybe...nice flavor, malty yet with a powdery (as in talcum), medicinal note, probably the house yeast and possible french hops like striessel spalt or something. A complex yet ultimately simple to enjoy beer, great new effort from this venerable and AMAZING  brewery

La Bavaisienne blonde 6.5% abv., bottle 25cl. Delirium cafe, Brussel. Aromas of sweet wort,  malt and just a bit citrussy. Tastes sweet/bitterish, very malty and fruity. Finishes more bitter(real nice shifting taste). Very balanced, very good.
